posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hello All,

Herewith please find a fairly heavily re-worked and improved version of this adaptable dwarf.

Harding has been played through a couple of SP environments: Aielund - with companions - and solo through Sou/HotU/ongoing in Sands of Fate. Poorly, on my part, I had until recently believed PvM to mean Player versus Machine, rather than Monster, thus thought all PvM builds were for soloists (D'oh). He does, fortunately, play well with others, but is equally happy working alone (sounds like a typical CV now). He's also very playable at all levels, and very good at staying alive - even solo he only died once in my playthroughs pre-epic, and that was my own dumb fault for confusing what he was already immune to with what he wasn't - flogging all my antidote pots when only immune to disease was not smart.

Changes and History

Initially a Monk 30/CoT 6/Fighter 4, with the 4 levels of Fighter taken pre-epic and the then 6 levels of CoT all in epic, I was more than happy to take on board suggestions for improvement - particulary in saves and improved WIS without sacrificing AB or AC - from, primarily HipRedux, through an intervention from the currently absent but no less worthy Tatooed Monk's Temple Guardian (Unarmed version). The initial design concept, fermenting in my grey matter while playing through a different Monk build in Aielund (Empyre's Order of the Wyrm: Unarmed version) seemed to then take on the other side of the debate between Valerfor and Maximillian Kane about the various merits/downsides to a build like this in Valerfor's Iron Fist Monk (Monk 35/Fighter 5) thread.

Having mentioned Aielund, in that environment I would loose Great Fortitude, insert SkFocus:Discipline at L6, then Iron Will at 9 and LReflex at 18. I'd also drop Search skills to 6(9), improve Heal to 2(5) and insert 7 points of Concentration (10)  early on in the schemata. That should be sufficient to avoid taunts early on, and avoid getting dropped on your arse all the time in Part 2. It's expedient, but doesn't radically alter the build (Fort saves drop to 33, which remains more than solid, and Disc improves to 46 (57)).

Do please feel free to allocate the 21 skill points not in Discipline, Tumble or Spellcraft elsewhere in any given different environment/campaign. It might be worth noting that Harding, while STR-based, is not a Dev Crit build - which is only useable in some environments, while non-Dev Crit is useable everywhere. Oh, and the WF in Kama is only taken to access CoT, although there's nothing wrong with having some slashing capabilities!

I've enjoyed playing him, and hope others will too.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
I think your skill set is about as good as can be drawn up given the total you have to work with so no comments there.

Otherwise, there are some class distribution alternatives that may help open up more universally-useful options.

First off, you can increase your BAB with more CoT pre-epic.  But before going further down this path I have a question:  What made you decide that SR 44 is an important goal? Anything other than a pure monk's SR 67 build will never achieve mage killer status so am interested to understand how you arrived at this number.  It seems unnecessarily costly, but am sure you have reasons based on the specific content that you are planning to employ the build within.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks Both,

@ Empyre - I'm a dipstick. You're right, of course. Skill Focus in Discipline might therefore be a better choice, given that the Fort save would still be strong enough without the extra 2 points. It was always about being able to function decently early on - much as taking Iron Will and the Concentration and Heal skills was

@ Hip - the above point demonstrates what I'm trying to achieve with this build. I want him to stay alive, and preferably upright, during his adolescence. One thing I've noticed here, and it's probably to do with the great and good spending a lot of time at L40 or thereabouts in PWs (virtually the opposite of where I play), is that many builds are waek as dishwater pre-epic, certainly as far as defences are concerned. To that end, lots of pre-epic Monk helps immeasurably. 16 levels gives +3 AC, 50% speed increase and +10 to all saves, as well as SR of 26, and immunity to disease and poison. Even if I took all the CoT levels pre-epic it would only give +1 to AB, and the +3 to the saves are more than mitigated by the rest of the Monk's repetoire. If anything, I noticed a slackening off of durability between levels 22 and 26, and I'm not sure why. For me, the race is then on to get to Monk 20 for the immunity to mind effects and DR20 (admittedly only at +1, but meaning you can ignore most of the mundane attacks), with a passing hat-tip to L18 for the 50% concealment. Hence my decisions.

However, I'm fairly flexible on the SR 44 question. At level 30 I'd have SR 40 anyway, and there are 2 Monk BFs at 25 and 30. I dismissed the idea of collecting a mere 2 more points, but was tempted by 4. Otherwise, those feats would have gone to Epic Energy Resistance. Those two bonus feats were, however, incidental. I wanted the additional +2AC, saves, additional +10SR and +30% speed that comes with Monk 30 over Monk 20. I don't believe I had any other viable alternatives as far as the feats go (Epic Toughness being a coward's way out, I believe), though I would be happy to be proved wrong.

Cheers!

posts.author: Stagmeister

The +8 vs spells comes from the +4 from Spellcraft, +2 from Dwarf and +2 from Monk level 3. Admittedly, the latter is vs Mind Spells, and thus becomes redundant post L20 Monk, so I can rewrite to accommodate that.

You mentioned Tatooed Monk's builds in another forum, but alas I couldn't find them. Sorry, I'm sure that's my fault somehow. I therefore have no insight as to his reasons for targeting high SR.

For myself, I probably ought to clarify that I am not targeting high SR, it is a happy by-product of Monk, which simply feeds into the mix. Let me be clear, this is a build constructed to maximise natural defences, while being very capable in attack. I'm not looking for a specific mage-killer, in the same way that I'm not looking for an undead-hunter or dragon-slayer. I want a rounded build that won't just collapse at any given attack.

I assume from your "cost +2 universal saves, 2 feats" line, that you're thinking about more CoT levels. Firstly, you're wrong about the saves, sorry. More CoT certainly does give the +2 (assuming 4 more levels), but Monk gives bonuses to all three saves every three levels, and with Will being the only one that might need addressing, that's an overall loss of 1, which I don't believe is an issue when set against the +2AC (admittedly +1 that dropping 4 levels would entail). Secondly, I'm not entirely sure what I'd beneficially do with those 2 extra feats. Happy to be enlightened.

As to your iteration of minimum levels I was looking for at the outset (which, incidentally, I don't recall you asking before): min AB 26 (BAB 40); AC 30; SR 40.

I'm not entirely sure why you wish to disregard the speed factor, but I'll bow to experience.

Cheers, Hip, thanks for the questions - they always make me think about why I did what I did! Hope these answers suffice.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Thanks for the clarification, Empyre.   I use charts for all this stuff so my mind gets lazy at times just relying on them.

@Stagmeister... for hasted monks the relative increase from monk speed is only 6.7% per 3 levels (or 2.2% per level, if you prefer).  You divide by 150 instead of 100.

So for low-magic environments where haste effect is limited to spellcasting buffs only (usually w/o speed pots/scrolls as well), use the standard +10% chart.
For mid- to high magic where hasting resources are common, substitute 6.7, 13.3, 20, 27, 33.3, 40, 47, 53.3, 60, 67, respectively.

If you check the last build I posted a few weeks back you should notice that I just capitalized the word "Terror" in the title (I'll be switching it back to proper format after you see the result). 

All I did was edit the original (top) post which accesses the title line.  Also, please do me a favor.  It may seem picky, but refrain from using caps in your titles.  The reason being that I have limited space in the spreadsheet column so titles with caps tend to get truncated (like "HARDING BRIGHTW".  "Proper" formatting (the one that capitalizes only the first letter of proper nouns) takes up much less horizontal column space so I must run a calculation to change caps myself, another step that slows things down further, if you get my drift. 

Abbreviating the class names in the title (some contributors do this for long class names like Red Dragon Disciple) is fine, but within the context of my effort explicity, it doesn't matter either way because the combo split is handled without use of the actual title text.

What I suggest is to use the original build as the final, completed display even though you are still working out the bugs.  Keep a "Changes" section at the end of the post detailing any decisions about why your build has changed as input was being received by the membership or your own analysis found worthwhile refinements.  That way it won't appear that our replies are referring to a non-existent value or design.  I mean, we ARE all crazy and delusional here, but don't fuel that fire, eh?

On the legacy ECB boards, an admin was needed to adjust the build to reflect the latest and greatest improvements but here on forumer that power lies solely with the author.  Thanks for staying in touch regularly while we refine your conceptualization, Stagmeister.
